required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Early Versus Late Interval Postpartum Copper Intrauterine Device Insertion
clinical_study.official_title: Early (4th Week) Versus Late (6thweek) Interval Postpartum Copper Intrauterine Device Insertion: a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The optimal interval between pregnancies is debated, but a duration greater than 11-18 months has been suggested as reducing complications in the subsequent pregnancy. Improved birth spacing can be a key benefit use of long-acting reversible contraception, but delay to initiation can still be problematic.So women who have recently given birth can be cost-effectively targeted for family planning education and engagement because often they are already connected with health professionals

primary_outcome.measure: The number of participants use the device
primary_outcome.description: number of women place the intrauterine device within 6 weeks

arm_group.arm_group_label: insertion by the end of the 4th week postpartum
insertion by the end of the 6th week postpartum

intervention.arm_group_label: insertion by the end of the 4th week postpartum
insertion by the end of the 6th week postpartum

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Delivered (vaginal or Cesarean) a singleton living baby â‰¥28weeks gestation. Women desire birth spacing for one year or more. Women who will accept to participate in the study and follow up.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Known uterine anomalies.
2. Women with previous ectopic pregnancy.
3. Presence of postpartum pyrexia.
4. Women with history of postpartum hemorrhage in the last delivery either primary or secondary.
5. Retained products of conception.
6. History of previous uterine perforation.
7. Anticipation of difficulty of subsequent follow-up with the women.
8. Women with uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension.
9. Women who wish to use other contraceptive methods.

reference.citation: Shachar BZ, Mayo JA, Lyell DJ, Baer RJ, Jeliffe-Pawlowski LL, Stevenson DK, Shaw GM. Interpregnancy interval after live birth or pregnancy termination and estimated risk of preterm birth: a retrospective cohort study. BJOG. 2016 Nov;123(12):2009-2017. doi: 10.1111/1471-0528.14165. Epub 2016 Jul 13.
